context: A micro-coring device was used to further allow for recovering a micro soil core of approximately 2 g from the middle of the previously collected soil core, as previously described (Côme et al., 2008). Soil samples were placed into 20 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-sealed headspace vials, after removal of roots and other woody materials. In January 2016, passive soil gas measurements were conducted at 8 sampling points in the PW67 zone by installing a polyethylene pipe (diameter 44 mm) to a depth of 1.5 m, with a porous section between 1.5 m and 1 m depth, allowing the diffusion of hydrocarbon volatile organic carbon (HVOC) in the pipe. TENAX®-GR (Sigma) 40/80 mesh porous polymer adsorbent tubes (150 mg), which have a high affinity for CE, were placed on top of sealed pipes for 3 h.Analytical method Concentrations of TCE and PCE in tree cores and soil cores were determined by solid phase microextraction gas chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry (SPME-GC-MS) using a gas chromatograph Agilent 7890 GC equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer 5975C MSD (Agilent), and a Gerstel MPS (MultiPurpose Sampler) SPME mode with a 85 μM carboxen/polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) fiber (Supelco-Sigma). Upon receipt in the laboratory at sampling day, samples were prepared for analysis within the next day. Before analysis, both tree and soil core samples were allowed to equilibrate in the vials for 12 h at room temperature (20 °C) and SPME fibers were conditioned in the GC injection port by fully exposing them for 30 min at 280 °C. Samples were heated at 30 °C in an incubator for 30 min in order to avoid a potential influence of ambient temperature fluctuations.
